titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Kan'ichi Asakawa Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 08:06

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, diaries, writings, notes, photographs, and miscellanea documenting the personal life and professional career of Kan'ichi Asakawa, a professor of Japanese history at Yale University and author of several books on Japanese history.

langmaterial.language: The materials are in English, Chinese, and Japanese.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Boxes 1-10, 51-52, and 56-57 are available on microfilm (9715 frames on 10 reels, 35mm) from Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library, at cost. Order no. HM201.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the estate of Kan'ichi Asakawa, 1946-1948; Mary Rouse, 1984; Yoshio Abe, 1984; and Jerome Pollitt, 1990; transferred from the East Asian Collection Curator, 2000-2001, 2004. Transferred from the East Asia Library, 2009.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiotape, videotape, and motion picture films, as well as preservation masters and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers needing to consult the original materials should consult the finding aid for policies governing reproduction for access.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Series I, Correspondence (Boxes 1-4), Series II, Diaries (Boxes 5-6), and Series III, Writings, Notes, and Miscellanea (Boxes 7-10, 51-52, and 56-57) are available on microfilm. Patrons must use FILM HM 201 instead of the originals.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Kan'ichi Asakawa Papers (MS 40). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in three series and additions: I. Correspondence, 1895-1955. II. Diaries, 1900-1948. III. Writings, Notes, and Miscellanea, 1894-1940.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Kan'ichi Asakawa was born in Nihommatsu, Japan, on December 20, 1873. He graduated from Waseda University (B.L., 1895), Dartmouth College (B.L., 1899), and Yale University (Ph.D., 1902). He taught Japanese history at Yale (1906-1942, professor emeritus, 1942-1948), and served as curator of Chinese and Japanese Collections (1907-1948). Asakawa wrote several books and articles on Japanese history. He died in West Wardsboro, Vermont, on August 11, 1948.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, diaries, writings, notes, photographs, and miscellanea documenting the personal life and professional career of Kan'ichi Asakawa, a professor of Japanese history at Yale University and author of several works on Japanese history. The Asakawa Papers are organized in three series:

SERIES I, CORRESPONDENCE, 1895-1955, contains letters to and from family members, beginning with Asakawa's first years in the United States, as a student at Dartmouth College and Yale University (1895-1902). Letters are written in both Japanese and English, depending on the correspondent. Additional correspondence relates to Asakawa's academic and literary interests, particularly his interest in Esperanto, an artificial language. Asakawa corresponded with David Morris and other members of the International Auxiliary Language Association on this topic. Letters written during World War II focus on the reaction of individuals to Japanese-Americans living in the United States and Asakawa's thoughts on this subject are often recorded in letters. A draft of a letter Asakawa wrote for President Franklin Delano Roosevelt to send to the Japanese emperor in order to prevent hostilities from commencing in 1941 is also arranged in this series.

SERIES II, DIARIES, 1900-1948, contains several volumes of personal journals from 1900-1925 and 1940-1948. Asakawa's early journals are those of a college student and young educator, and contain many references to the differences in culture he encountered as an immigrant from Japan. Later journals detail Asakawa's personal and professional activities, and, once again, material written during the years of World War II focuses on the responsibilities and treatment of Japanese-Americans.

SERIES III, WRITINGS, NOTES, AND MISCELLANEA, 1894-1940, consists of articles, essays, notes, photographs, student papers and other materials. The bulk of material relates to Japanese history, although a section of "Notes" contains research files on modern European and French history in addition to extensive files on Japanese history. Under the heading "Japanese chronicles" is a group of research notes on a wide variety of Japanese historical topics from 1172-1945. Material relating to the Yale Association of Japan (folders 288-292) and the Yale Japanese Club (folder 296) is also arranged in this series.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is arranged in two sections: General and Select. General is arranged in chronological order. Select is arranged in alphabetical order, with résumés filed at the end of the section.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: These materials are available on microfilm. Patrons must use FILM HM 201 instead of the originals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains diaries arranged in chronological order, with no material for the years 1926-1939.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: These materials are available on microfilm. Patrons must use FILM HM 201 instead of the originals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains material arranged in alphabetical order by topic, with "miscellanea" filed at the end of the section.

did.unittitle: "Gifts of the Yale Association of Japan"
Abe Yoshio, Saigo no Nihonjin: Asakawa Kanichi no shogai
Correspondence from Kan'ichi Asakawa to others
Shortscript: A New Rapid Handwriting, by A. Maertz, and H. Asakawa's analysis of
Correspondence to Hartley Simpson pertaining to Kan'ichi Asakawa
Notes by Hartley Simpson pertaining to Kan'ichi Asakawa's diary
List of history courses pertaining primarily to Japan
Correspondence between George Pierson and Hideo Kaneko pertaining to Kaneko's tribute to Kan'ichi Asakawa in Nota Bene (transferred from Librarian's Office on 1991 Jan 8)
Unidentified [sent to Asakawa c/o Waseda University Library]
Untitled glossary of terms [presumably handwritten by Asakawa]
Kokeshi doll [traditional wooden doll presented to Yale by Taka Okochi, mayor of Nihommatsu, Japan, hometown of Asakawa]

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

did.unittitle: Telementary '94 Maboroshi no daitoryoshinsho - Kaisen o soshi sh'yoto shita otoko [videotape of Japanese television program documenting Asakawa's efforts to have President Roosevelt write a letter to the Japanese emperor just before the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor]

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site. Copies of commercially produced audiovisual materials contained in this collection cannot be made for researcher use outside of the repository.

did.unittitle: Asakawa's notes on a lecture given by Oya on art in the Meiji period
Paper on Byron submitted to Tokyo Senmon Gakko (predecessor to Waseda University) seminar?
Undergraduate thesis by Asakawa at Tokyo Senmon Gakko (predecessor to Waseda University)
Letter to Asakawa from an unidentified sender in Tokyo
Document on the language of Izu Peninsula, author unknown
Lecture notes on ethics by Asakawa
Miscellaneous, possibly notes from a lecture attended by Asakawa
Photographic prints of Asakawa with a brief description of each

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The prints include school, family, and passport photographs, with an English translation of captions.
